fgwGuidePage.title: Farming God's Way Guide
fgwGuidePage.description: A sustainable, no-till, faith-based agricultural solution for the poor.
fgwGuidePage.intro: Farming God's Way (FGW) is not just a technology, but a biblically-based, management, and technological solution for the agricultural needs of the poor. It's about being faithful stewards of the land God has given us. Below are the core principles.

principles.title: No-Tillage
principles.summary: Protect the soil by not plowing it. This preserves the God-given soil structure.
howTo: Create permanent planting stations (holes) instead of ridges.
Only dig where you will plant the seed.
Walk on permanent pathways to avoid compacting your planting soil.
whyItWorks: Prevents soil erosion by wind and water.
Protects soil life and fungal networks.
Dramatically increases water infiltration and retention.
Reduces labor and fuel costs associated with plowing.
principles.imageAlt: A field with no-tillage planting stations

principles.title: God's Blanket
principles.summary: Keep the soil 100% covered with a thick layer of organic matter, just like in a forest.
howTo: Gather dry organic matter like grass, straw, leaves, or maize stover.
Apply a thick mulch (at least 10-15 cm) across the entire plot.
Never burn your crop residues; use them for mulch.
When planting, make a small opening in the mulch for your seed.
whyItWorks: Saves significant soil moisture, reducing water needs.
Feeds soil life as it decomposes, building rich topsoil.
Protects the soil from the direct heat of the sun.
principles.imageAlt: A field covered in a thick blanket of mulch

principles.title: High Standards
principles.summary: Do everything on time, to a high standard, with no waste, and with joy.
howTo: Prepare the land well before the first rains.
Plant at the optimal time for your region and crop.
Follow precise measurements for planting depth and spacing.
Manage your resources (seed, inputs, time) wisely to avoid wastage.
whyItWorks: Maximizes the genetic potential of the seed.
Ensures the crop gets the full benefit of the early rains.
Leads to higher yields and greater profitability.
principles.imageAlt: A farmer carefully planting seeds in a well-prepared field

knfInputsPage.title: KNF Inputs Assistant
knfInputsPage.description: Create, track, and manage your Korean Natural Farming inputs.

recipeData.name: Fermented Plant Juice (FPJ)
recipeData.description: A fermented extract of a plant's sap and chlorophyll. Rich in enzymes and microorganisms, it's a potent growth enhancer for plants.
ingredients: 1kg of fast-growing plant parts (e.g., sweet potato tips, bamboo shoots)
steps: Collect plant material before sunrise when it is most potent. Do not wash.
Roughly chop the plant material.
Add an equal weight of brown sugar and mix well.
Pack tightly into a clay pot or glass jar, filling to about 2/3 capacity.
Cover with a breathable cloth and store in a cool, dark place.
Allow to ferment for about 7 days.
recipeData.usage: Dilution rate: 1:500 to 1:1000 with water. Applied as a foliar spray or soil drench.

recipeData.name: Fish Amino Acid (FAA)
recipeData.description: A potent liquid fertilizer made from fish waste, rich in nitrogen and amino acids. Excellent for boosting plant growth, especially during the vegetative stage.
steps: Chop the fish parts into small pieces.
In a container, layer the fish parts and brown sugar, starting and ending with a layer of sugar.
Fill the container to about 2/3 capacity and cover with a breathable cloth.
Store in a cool, dark place and allow to ferment for at least 3-6 months.
recipeData.usage: Dilution rate: 1:1000 with water. Primarily used as a soil drench.

seedStartingPage.title: Seed Starting Master Guide
seedStartingPage.description: Give your crops the best possible start. Learn the art and science of starting seeds indoors for a stronger, healthier, and more productive season.
seedStartingPage.intro: Starting seeds indoors gives you a significant head start on the growing season, protects young plants from pests and harsh weather, and allows you to cultivate varieties that might not otherwise have time to mature in your climate. This guide covers the essential steps from choosing your setup to transplanting your seedlings.

sections.title: Why Start Seeds Indoors?
sections.intro: There are several key advantages to starting seeds indoors versus direct sowing in the garden:

points.def: Start weeks or months before your last frost date, which is crucial for plants that need a long time to mature like tomatoes, peppers, and eggplants.
Seedlings are shielded from harsh weather (heavy rain, wind, cold snaps) and common pests (slugs, birds, cutworms).
You can control the temperature, moisture, and light to create the perfect conditions for seeds to sprout.
A packet of seeds is far cheaper than buying established nursery plants, especially for large plantings.
You gain access to thousands of unique and heirloom varieties available from seed catalogs that you'll never find at a local garden center.

sections.title: Key Supplies for Seed Starting
sections.intro: Gathering the right supplies before you start will make the process smoother and more successful. You'll need:
steps: Containers: Seed starting trays, cell packs, peat pots, or even recycled yogurt cups (with drainage holes) all work well.
Seed Starting Mix: Use a sterile, soilless mix specifically designed for seed starting. It's lightweight and holds moisture well, preventing diseases that can affect seedlings.
Seeds: Choose high-quality seeds from a reputable supplier. Check the packet for information on planting depth and timing.
Light Source: A sunny, south-facing window can work, but a simple fluorescent shop light or dedicated LED grow light provides much better results, preventing 'leggy' (tall and weak) seedlings.
Heat Mat (Optional): Many seeds, especially warm-weather crops like peppers, germinate much faster with bottom heat. A seedling heat mat is a great investment.
Watering Can/Spray Bottle: A gentle way to water your seeds without dislodging them.
Labels: Don't forget to label your trays! Use popsicle sticks, plastic plant tags, or even masking tape.

sections.title: Step-by-Step Planting Guide
sections.intro: Follow these steps to plant your seeds for optimal germination:
steps: Moisten the Mix: Before filling your containers, put your seed starting mix into a bucket or tub and slowly add warm water, mixing with your hands until it's damp like a wrung-out sponge, but not soaking wet.
Fill Containers: Fill your containers with the moistened mix, gently firming it down but not compacting it. Leave about a quarter-inch of space at the top.
Sow the Seeds: Plant 2-3 seeds per cell or pot. A general rule of thumb is to plant a seed twice as deep as it is wide. Check the seed packet for specific instructions.
Cover and Label: Lightly cover the seeds with more mix or vermiculite, then gently firm the surface. Immediately label your tray with the plant variety and the date sown.
Water Gently: Water the surface gently with a spray bottle or from the bottom by placing your trays in a pan of water. This prevents seeds from washing away.

Provide Warmth & Cover: Place the trays in a warm spot or on a heat mat. Cover with a plastic dome or plastic wrap to retain humidity until the seeds sprout. Remove the cover as soon as you see the first signs of green.

sections.title: Caring for Your Seedlings
sections.intro: Once your seeds have sprouted, their needs change. Proper care now is crucial for strong plants.
steps: Light is Critical: As soon as seeds sprout, they need abundant light. Place them under grow lights for 14-16 hours a day, keeping the lights just a few inches above the tops of the plants. If using a window, rotate the trays daily to prevent leaning.
Watering: Keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's often best to water from the bottom to encourage deep root growth.

Thinning: Once the seedlings have their first set of 'true leaves' (the second set that appears), choose the strongest-looking seedling in each cell and snip the others at the soil line with scissors. This prevents disturbing the roots of the winner.
Fertilizing: Begin feeding your seedlings with a diluted, balanced liquid fertilizer (at quarter-strength) after they have 2-3 sets of true leaves. Feed about once a week.
Air Circulation: A gentle fan blowing on your seedlings for a few hours a day helps prevent disease and strengthens their stems.

sections.title: Hardening Off & Transplanting
sections.intro: 'Hardening off' is the process of gradually acclimating your tender indoor-grown plants to the harsh conditions outdoors.
steps: Start 1-2 Weeks Before Transplanting: About 7-14 days before your last frost date, begin the process.
Day 1: Place seedlings in a shady, protected spot outdoors for 1-2 hours.
Gradual Exposure: Each day, increase the amount of time they spend outside by an hour or two, gradually introducing them to more direct sunlight and wind.
Bring Them In: Bring the plants back inside each night if temperatures drop significantly.
Transplant: After a week or two of hardening off, your plants will be ready for their new home in the garden. Choose a calm, overcast day to transplant to minimize shock. Water them in well.

sections.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
sections.intro: Avoid these common pitfalls for a more successful seed starting experience:

points.def: This is the most common cause of seedling death. It leads to 'damping off,' a fungal disease that rots stems at the soil line. Let the soil surface dry slightly between waterings.
Causes 'leggy,' weak seedlings that stretch for the light. If you don't have grow lights, a very bright south-facing window is the next best thing.
Eagerness is great, but starting seeds too early leads to large, root-bound plants that struggle after transplanting. Check your seed packet and count backwards from your local last frost date.
Overcrowded seedlings will compete for light and nutrients, resulting in weak plants for all. It's hard, but thinning is necessary for strong individual plants.

familyFarmPage.title: Integrated Family Farm Model (200 sqm)
familyFarmPage.description: A holistic, diversified model for a small family farm designed for resilience, food security, and supplemental income.
familyFarmPage.intro: This model demonstrates how a small plot of land (e.g., 20m x 10m) can be transformed into a productive, integrated system that mimics natural ecosystems. It combines various elements that support each other, reducing waste and external inputs while maximizing diversity and yield.
familyFarmPage.diagramCaption: Conceptual diagram of the 200 sqm Integrated Family Farm Model.

zones.title: Overall Layout & Principles
zones.imageAlt: An overview of a lush, diversified small farm.
description: The 200 square meter (20m x 10m) plot is designed for intensive, regenerative production. The core idea is to create a closed-loop system where each component supports another, minimizing waste and maximizing resource use.

Water is the central, life-giving element, with the pond serving as a reservoir, a source of nutrients, and a habitat. The layout is designed to use gravity and natural flows for irrigation and nutrient distribution.

subSections.title: Resource Cycling
content: Waste from one component becomes a resource for another (e.g., chicken manure fertilizes crops, crop residues feed chickens).

subSections.title: Diversity over Monoculture
content: A wide variety of plants and animals creates resilience against pests and diseases.

subSections.title: Vertical Stacking
content: Using trellises and multi-story planting to maximize yield in a small space.

subSections.title: Edge Effect
content: The boundary between the pond and the land is a highly productive zone for moisture-loving plants.

zones.title: Raised Vegetable & Herb Beds (100 sqm)
zones.imageAlt: Lush raised vegetable beds with a variety of greens and herbs.
description: This is the primary food production area, occupying half of the total space. Raised beds improve drainage, reduce soil compaction, and are easier to manage.
Intensive planting methods like intercropping (planting different crops together) and succession planting (replanting immediately after harvest) are used to maximize output throughout the year.

details.title: Crops
content: Leafy greens (lettuce, spinach), root vegetables (carrots, radishes), fruiting vegetables (tomatoes, peppers), legumes (beans, peas), and essential culinary/medicinal herbs.

details.title: Fertility
content: Maintained using compost from the farm's waste, chicken manure, and nutrient-rich water from the fish pond.

zones.title: Fruit Trees & Perennials (Integrated)
zones.imageAlt: A small orchard with various fruit trees and perennial plants.
description: Fruit trees are integrated along the borders and within the vegetable beds to provide a long-term food source, create microclimates, and add vertical structure.
These perennial plants require less annual work than vegetables and help build soil stability with their deep root systems.

details.title: Examples
content: Dwarf varieties of banana, papaya, mango, and citrus trees are excellent choices for small spaces. Perennials like moringa or passion fruit on a trellis can also be integrated.

zones.title: Fish Pond (15 sqm)
zones.imageAlt: A small, clear fish pond with tilapia and aquatic plants.
description: The fish pond is a key element of the integrated system. It acts as a water reservoir for irrigation during dry periods and provides a source of protein.
The nutrient-rich water from the pond, full of fish waste, is a natural, high-quality liquid fertilizer for the vegetable beds.

details.title: Species
content: Tilapia are a popular choice as they are hardy, fast-growing, and primarily vegetarian.

details.title: Aquatic Plants
content: Water spinach or duckweed can be grown on the surface to provide food for the fish and chickens, and for human consumption.

zones.title: Chicken Coop (5 sqm)
zones.imageAlt: A small, clean chicken coop with a few chickens.
description: A small flock of chickens (5-10) provides a consistent source of eggs and meat for the family.
Their manure is a powerful fertilizer for the compost pile, and they can be allowed to forage in harvested garden beds to clean up pests and weed seeds.

details.title: Integration
content: Positioning the coop next to the compost pile allows for easy transfer of manure. Chickens are fed with kitchen scraps and excess garden produce, reducing waste.

zones.title: Compost & Waste Management Area
description: This is the recycling hub of the farm. All organic 'waste'—kitchen scraps, garden residues, animal manure, and fallen leaves—is converted into 'black gold' (compost).
A simple three-bin system allows for one pile to be actively built, one to be 'cooking', and one to be ready for use, ensuring a continuous supply of high-quality soil amendment.

details.title: Function
content: Closes the nutrient loop on the farm, eliminating the need for synthetic fertilizers, improving soil structure, and increasing its water-holding capacity.

conclusion.title: A Model of Abundance
content: This 200 sqm model is more than just a farm; it's a living example of how to work with nature to create abundance in a small space.

It provides a diverse and nutritious diet, reduces reliance on external markets, generates a potential surplus for income, and builds a resilient system that can better withstand climate and economic shocks.
It's a pathway to food sovereignty and a healthier life for the family.
